[confused] I keep thinking about what Marcus said to me yesterday. [pause] Twenty years I've been a corrections officer, you know? Twenty years of— [bitter] I thought my job was to make their lives hard. Keep them in line. [slowly] But then this kid, this kid comes in for armed robbery, and I'm ready to just... [trailing off] 

[sigh] Something was different though. [curious] I actually, um, started talking to him. Like really talking. [warm] About his mom, about why he did it, about what he wanted before everything went wrong. [short pause] And I realized— [gasp softly] God, I've been doing this all wrong.

[very sincerely] These past six months, I've been running these circles, these restorative justice circles, and it's like— [excited] people are actually changing! [laugh] The recidivism rate in my block dropped forty percent. Forty! [passionately] I'm not just locking people up anymore, I'm actually— [voice breaking] I'm helping them heal.

[regretful] All those years I wasted being the tough guy. [mumbling] Being the punisher. [empathetically] When really, I mean, what people needed was someone to listen, to help them understand why they— [speeding up] why they hurt others, how to make it right. [relieved] I finally found what I'm actually good at. [chuckle] Who would've thought?
